text: How do people feel about the phrase _“consensual type-piracy”_ , Is it clear what it means?

elements.text: How do people feel about the phrase
“consensual type-piracy”
, Is it clear what it means?

text: I’m not a native speaker, but to me it sounds odd. Modules are not humans. You can’t hurt a module’s feelings.

elements.text: I’m not a native speaker, but to me it sounds odd. Modules are not humans. You can’t hurt a module’s feelings.

text: No, not sure what that means, TBH

elements.text: No, not sure what that means, TBH

text: As in, methods and/or types that are intended to be extensible but at your own risks? If so then consensual might not be the best word for it, since we rarely ask the original author for consent. Perhaps “permissible”?

elements.text: As in, methods and/or types that are intended to be extensible but at your own risks? If so then consensual might not be the best word for it, since we rarely ask the original author for consent. Perhaps “permissible”?

text: Designed / intended / specified?

elements.text: Designed / intended / specified?

text: Seems pretty clear to me.

elements.text: Seems pretty clear to me.

text: <@U8D9768Q6> can you give an example of it?

elements.text: can you give an example of it?

text: I’d say this: <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/pull/35778#issuecomment-635576085|https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/pull/35778#issuecomment-635576085>

elements.text: I’d say this:
https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/pull/35778#issuecomment-635576085

text: I.e. suggesting that FillArrays move its basic functionality to Base for use in Broadcast and such, and then have FillArrays.jl pirate those types with the blessing of Base.

elements.text: I.e. suggesting that FillArrays move its basic functionality to Base for use in Broadcast and such, and then have FillArrays.jl pirate those types with the blessing of Base.

text:
that was basically what I was thinking yes.
Things with explicit consent from the authors.
Other examples I had in mind.

ChainRulesCore <- ChainRules (both written by same people but seperated for interface reasons)

ColorTypes <- NamedColors (I literally had a discussion with Tim Holy saying “Can I override `@colorant_str` to add more colors?“)

text: We need a historian that knows the term for "commissioned pirates" those made made deals with the Queen of England to plunder and pillage on her behalf.

text: I like commissioned type piracy a lot. I'd say 'commissioned' implies an agreement.

text: this is only kind of related but it would be nice if there was a way to specify what all methods you needed to fully "implement" an interface e.g. what all methods do I need to define for object I want to work as an ::IO ?

text: Alright "commissioned type piracy" sounds legit after some thought.

elements.text: Alright "commissioned type piracy" sounds legit after some thought.

text:
"Hey, your package type pyrates a type from ChainRules!"
"No worries, they commissioned it so that ChainRulesCore could be a good base package."

elements.text:
"Hey, your package type pyrates a type from ChainRules!"
"No worries, they commissioned it so that ChainRulesCore could be a good base package."

text:
commissioned type piracy sounds wrong.
I could commission you to commit type piracy against someone else.
Where as I consented to have you to commit type piracy against me.

elements.text:
commissioned type piracy sounds wrong.
I could commission you to commit type piracy against someone else.
Where as I consented to have you to commit type piracy against me.

text: You commission me to commit piracy against your *repo*.

elements.text: You commission me to commit piracy against your
repo

text:
not necessarily though. When I asked Tim Holy if i could type pirate `@colorant_str` he said i could (he consented).
He never asked me to do so.

elements.text: not necessarily though. When I asked Tim Holy if i could type pirate

he said i could (he consented).

text:

The type pirate life commissioned me.```
